uh hello everybody um
my name is eric arlenson and i'm a

and i thank you very much for attending
my race summit talk of powering open
data hub
with ray another possible title for this
talk
as more direct with some of you to say
using jupiter
and ray in the cloud
so the basic organization of the talk is
going to be i'm going to talk about
why you might actually be interested
using jupiter with ray
and then i'm going to try to put open
data hub and jupiter
in some context for you i'm going to
talk about the architecture of
ray working with open data hub and
demonstrate demonstrate this deployment
in action and then last i'll
conclude with some of the community
collaborations that
helped make this possible
so to put to understand the motivations
i want you to consider like the actual
ray library ecosystem
out of the box ray has native support
for hyper parameter tuning
reinforcement learning distributed
training
and you know scale out to serving for
models
there are also community integrations
for all of the very popular
machine learning packages and data
science packages including like
xgboost das horvat tensorflow
sklearn there's a very long list you can
see at the link at the bottom
but the main thing i want to bring to
your attention
is that all of these libraries
have already been used by data
scientists using jupiter for quite a
while
and so it makes a lot of sense
to consider whether or not you could say
well what if we take
ray with all its integrations these
packages and also
use it as backing compute for the same
libraries from a jupiter interface to
give you the full power of jupiter's
interactive and literate programming
experience
and today specifically also i'll be
talking about using
these tools as hosted using cloud
platforms
and in my case i'll be talking about
cloud platforms the kubernetes
and openshift
so when i first began this investigation
of course
the current version of the ray library
is ray 1 point
x and ray 1.x had a architectural
requirement that if you want to connect
to the ray cluster you had to do it
while you were on the physical node that
the ray head was running on
and so this means that if you wanted to
use jupiter
with ray you would actually have to run
some kind of pod or container
where jupiter and the ray head mode were
running simultaneously in the same pot
now if you get this to work at
all it's not actually a great cloud
architecture because of course it
violates
a good you know separation of concerns
where
different components are running inside
their own separate pods
however by the time i began looking into
this issue
of course development of the upcoming
raid 2.0 was already well underway
and ray 2.0
is being redesigned to support a true
client server connection between clients
and the right head
of course this is a total game changer
because it allows the jupiter pod to run
independently as it already does in most
environments
and simply connect to the ray head which
is running in its own separate pods
and talking to the ray workers so this
is a much cleaner architecture much
easier to get working
so when i talk about consuming jupiter
um the way i actually implemented this
is to
use jupiter as provided by the open data
hub project and so i want to talk a
little bit about
what that means and why it helped
so there's different ways to describe
odh um the first might be is it it's
an open source downstream and
specifically it's a
downstream of the kubeflow project
and so this is a very typical pattern
red hat where we
take a popular open source upstream
and repackage a slight variation of it
and contribute most of the development
back to the upstream
open data hub is also a reference
platform
it's been used as a sort of proof of
concept that
popular machine learning tools that
operate in the cloud can all work
together to
support you know integrated data science
workflows
now it's also fairly federated and by
that i mean it's
the integrations are fairly loose and of
course they're all running
in the cloud and that means that it's
easy to
mix and match the tools install them in
an a la carte sort of basis
it also means that it's very easy of
course to simply spin up other tools
that you want to work with
so obviously this property made it extra
easy to you know consider
adding a tool like ray into the mix
lastly open data hub is what we call a
meta operator and what that means is you
can consume
odh from something like red hat's
openshift operator hub
and the operator will in turn install
other operators like for instance
the cough customs the operator or the
apache spark operator or prometheus
and so again you're getting you know a
la carte
menu style access to different tools
through a single meta operator
experience
so what's it actually like to do data
science with odh
the tools in odh provide fairly good
coverage for a typical machine learning
workflow where you you know go all the
way from setting business goals to
data preparation to model training and
then finally to
actual application development
deployment
of course this is not a waterfall
process so all these
um steps iterate against each other
um it supplies tooling for
most of the you know data science
persona that you'd encounter
everywhere from business stakeholders
through data engineering
and the actual data scientists doing
model development
and the application nit staff
that do you know development and
deployment you can see here
a bunch of the tools that you can get
through
open data hub or kubeflow
and how they map onto the different
stages and data personas
so at red hat we don't just advocate
using tools like open data hub we
actually use open data hub internally
we've used it to provide data science
support for things like
application log monitoring and anomaly
detection
you know cluster metric analysis and
also analysis of the data coming back
from
customer support interactions
so to help you understand
architecturally where i went with this
helps to do an analogy um
you know open data hub already supports
using apache
spark as backing compute for jupiter
and it works like this if you log into
the jupiter hub launcher from open data
hub
it will of course as the standard
launcher does is spin you up a jupiter
environment
where you can create your notebooks but
in the background
it's also referring to a
data structure which is called a single
user profile
which knows how to tell it how to spin
up spark clusters
part of how it does that is it talks to
service template objects which basically
explain to it how to you know what what
actual kubernetes objects it needs to
create to
stand up a service and so it uses that
we have it set for how to you know spin
up spark
clusters with workers and executors
and so by the time you have your jupiter
environment up
you have an also a dedicated spark
cluster for you to use that you can
connect to from jupiter
now looking at the single user profile
and
service template um there's absolutely
nothing exotic about this
they're just kubernetes config map
objects and so it's just
data driven configuration
and so there's nothing specific to
standing up a spark cluster and so it
obviously brings up the questions well
could i
create these objects and tell how to
spin up a ray cluster
especially using the new ray 2.0 with
client
server capabilities
and spoiler of course it is possible to
do this um here's a fragment of the
ray single user profile you can see
again there's nothing exotic here
it's the typical stuff you see in
kubernetes objects and data about what
kind of images to use
um what kind of resources to request
you know some environment variables you
can return
to help you connect to the cluster that
it creates and of course there's a
pointer to this
ray cluster service template object
so here is what that looks like again
it's nothing but some data
you know held in a config map um
and it you know describes metadata like
how to name the cluster for the user
it describes how many workers to allow
um
the full specification for a ray cluster
object is
quite long if you ever see it so i'm not
going to show the whole thing but
again there's nothing special about this
you can just
use you know the raycluster object stick
it in this service template config map
and
odh understands how to work with it
so now i've described the architecture i

the
shared heritage of both
rey and apache spark i thought i would

and so of course ray pi is like the
spark pi
monte carlo estimate of the value of pi
using parallel computing
so again these images i deployed all
have the array libraries pre-installed
and so i can just

i can connect directly to my ray cluster
you can see that it has provided me this

i

can be executed in any order or

here instead of just connecting directly
i first
test to see if i've already connected
that's a nice little idiom to use if
you're actually doing ray
inside a notebook
and so now i've got my connection
because of course we're in notebooks i
can use literate programming to help
explain what it is i'm actually thinking
about doing
and so here's a diagram it shows what
it's like to do
a monte carlo estimation of pi you just
generate
a bunch of random points on the unit
square
and you count how many of those points
actually landed inside
the corresponding circle which are the
red points versus outside
which are the black points and once you
have these uh two counts
as the easy formula to apply you simply
take the number of points that are
inside the circle
multiply it by four and divide it by the
total number of points you generated
and there you have an estimate of pi
that converges
although very slowly so
if you've ever used apache spark you
know that
doing this computation looks a lot like
the thing you see here which is you
take some seed data and you have to
parallelize it over the network
and ship it off to spark executors and
at that point you can just run
filters so you can say okay i take my
seed data map it into randomized data
filter it to make sure that i get the
count of things that's inside the circle
and lastly i return
the count of those items and then apply
my formula as you see
now it turns out an array which has a
more
general compute model i don't actually
have to create seed data
i can just tell rey it was like here's a
function i'll tag it with ray remote as
you see in this cell
and i just tell it to use a python
generator at the point of computation to
generate my random data directly
and then count it so i never actually
have to ship data over the network the
only thing i have to
bring back is a single integer count of
the number of points and so this is
actually a
more efficient and direct way to do the
same thing we used to do in spark
so i'll simply tell jupiter how to
define this function
and we can see what it looks like to
call it so if i simply call this
function using
the dot remote that ray added form you
can see it doesn't return a result
because of course ray's compute model is
lazy
all it returned for me was like a
placeholder for a computation
so to actually run the computation of
course use ray.get
if i do that and i print out the
corresponding estimate of pi
i get it very quickly of course because
i only used a thousand points
and as you can see the estimate is as
expected fairly terrible
but it is an estimate
so of course the real point of using
platforms like ray is
to do more parallelized computing so
it's easy to do
i just call a bunch of invocations
of my count in circle function and
send them off to ray and ray does its
job parallelizing and so if i run this i
get a parallelized version
of the estimate of pi
using many more points but getting right
to parallelize the computation for me
you can see it returns in about 10
seconds and
as expected the estimate for pi is
actually a little bit better it's
at least down to 3.14
so each of these parts we computed can
be viewed as its own
estimate so i can actually use the power

they're all similar but they're not the

and again using using jupiter it's easy

doing ray of jupiter i'm actually

calling out to do computations writing

we see that right away we get a result
